title: Voice of the Mirror: MPs know how to cure GP crisis - it's time to get to work
text:

There are two ways of looking at GPs. As stalwart frontline troops of the NHS. Or as the poor bloody infantry fighting a rearguard action against overwhelming odds.

As family doctors know only too well, both descriptions are true.

And overwork, stress and exhaustion are driving them out of medicine and into ­retirement in droves.

That only makes the problem of too few doctors for too many patients even worse.

We’ve already lost 1,600 GPs and another 7,000 are predicted to go before 2024.

This not only means patients suffering the agony of their illnesses not being caught early enough but extra costs to an already cash-strapped health service treating disease in its advanced stages.

(Image: Getty)

Yet diagnosis and remedy are only part of the job. GPs are also there to comfort and reassure, to be a family’s friend.

Patients are now waiting an average of 15 days for an appointment – often longer.

What we need is 30 million extra slots to cut down waits – and the way to get them is with 5,000 more GPs.

But this cannot happen overnight. It takes 10 years to train for general practice. That’s why we’re campaigning for action now.

The sooner the Government starts on this the better.

Hardly a credit

It’s bad enough having to claim Universal Credit in the first place.

But it is even worse to discover claimants are being slagged off behind their backs by those hired to help them navigate the confusing system.

Yet that is exactly what is happening at one call centre – and a horrified whistleblower gave us the tape to prove it.

This goes beyond mere workplace banter. These were foul slurs on vulnerable people.

To hold them in such contempt is contemptible. The principle behind UC is sound.

But in practice, its roll-out has been a ­shambles. And that’s because the Tories are unable to grasp how to make it work.

The Government needs to get a grip urgently. And if it cannot, then it must do what one of those noxious call centre managers viciously advocated for claimants.

Put a grenade under it.

Get it sorted

(Image: Getty)

Liquorice Allsorts are not as popular as they used to be, with sales down 10 per cent in the past year alone.

The sweets also fall foul of new recommendations, which say they should contain less than 50 per cent sugar.

We hope that the makers find a way of meeting this target without causing any change in the taste.

That way our, Allsorts would be all sorted.
description: Overwork, stress and exhaustion are forcing doctors in to retirement in their droves - and the government must act now
